normalised: So, you've found that perfect two B H K in Bandra, overlooking the Arabian Sea (dreamy, right?). But hold on, before you start planning that housewarming party with all your college buddies from I I T Bombay, let's talk about the unsung hero of every tenant's life: the Rental Agreement.

unnormalised: So, you've found that perfect 2BHK in Bandra, overlooking the Arabian Sea (dreamy, right?). But hold on, before you start planning that housewarming party with all your college buddies from IIT Bombay, let's talk about the unsung hero of every tenant's life: the Rental Agreement.
normalised: Think of it as the legal chai-biscuit to your renting relationship with your landlord, Mister Sharma. It lays down the ground rules and keeps things sweet and simple – preventing misunderstandings later. No one wants drama with their landlord, especially not during Diwali!

unnormalised: Think of it as the legal chai-biscuit to your renting relationship with your landlord, Mr. Sharma. It lays down the ground rules and keeps things sweet and simple – preventing misunderstandings later. No one wants drama with their landlord, especially not during Diwali!
normalised: What exactly should you be looking for? First off, the obvious: Rent amount (rupees thirty five thousand seems reasonable for Bandra these days, no?), security deposit (usually a couple of months’ rent), and the duration of the agreement (typically eleven months to avoid certain registration complexities, clever, huh?). Also, clearly understand the lock-in period. You don't want to lose your deposit if you decide to move after only six months.

normalised: But it's not just about the money. Pay close attention to clauses about maintenance responsibilities. Who’s responsible for fixing that leaky tap that's been driving you crazy since tenth october two thousand and twenty three? Is painting the apartment your job before you move out? These details can save you a lot of headaches (and rupees!) down the line.
